Studs Terkel talks with members of the Mattachine Midwest organization

BROADCAST: Feb. 19, 1970 | DURATION: 00:58:20

Synopsis

Content Warning: This conversation includes racially and/or culturally derogatory language and/or negative depictions of Black and Indigenous people of color, women, and LGBTQI+ individuals. Rather than remove this content, we present it in the context of twentieth-century social history to acknowledge and learn from its impact and to inspire awareness and discussion. Discussing homosexuality and American society and interviewing members of the Mattachine Midwest organization: Jim Bradford, Valerie Taylor (pen name of Velma N. Tate, 1913-1997), and Henry Weimhoff.

Jim Bradford I think [coughing] there a number of long term relationships that spring up, too, and you don't hear too much about them. The scuttlebutt has it that they're [coughing] quite rare. And possibly so for males than females for various reasons that we might delve into but they're not, they're not all that rare really. I was sitting down the other day and going in my own mind I probably know half a dozen if I rattle them off except, I know who have been together great lengths of time. Well my partner. I use the word "partner'. Some people say "lovers" but it sounds a little bit hackney to me. [coughing] My partner and I have been together, we've known each other for almost 17 years. We've lived together 15 years. So this proves that it can be done. Now, we've been together through thick and thin. I think the fact that there are no legal ties binding us may be, you know, some, some of the people when it comes to the thick or the thin, they, they just feel they've got a little bit more they can handle, so they separate. But I think the main thing is to have such a feeling for one another, that you do stick to the problems of [unintelligible]. Heterosexuals have told me that you know don't worry we go through this sort of thing all the time when there's a little bit of friction or some one problem one has got. And the fact that straight people can sort of reassure you in this way is helpful because after all it's just part of life. Doesn't mean any relationship is on the rocks [laughter] simply because you can't agree 100 percent with one another all the time or can't be together. This mania for being together I think is a, it's a good thing but it can be carried to such a exaggerated [life?].

Henry Weimhoff And if, we if we manifest some of us, feelings of inferiority and guilt, one can, one can show that to be the manifestations of this oppression which has been very all pervasive and has been very, very difficult at times to, to live with but nonetheless.

Valerie Taylor But straight people have it, too.

Jim Bradford Of course. I meant to try to squeeze this in earlier. There's a book called, "The Gay World,' by Martin Hoffman, a social psychiatrist. [coughing] He's brought up much of the same sort. Studs Terkel "The Gay World", by Martin Hoffman.

Jim Bradford He doesn't have this personal psychopathological approach. He has a sociological approach to it. It's really quite informing and revealing and inspires many of us to start [match striking] considering things from a new light.
